factoid: Prince Andrew went out into the hall.
Prince Andrew turned his shoulders to the footman who was helping him with his cloak.
Prince Andrew listened indifferently to his wife's chatter with Prince Hippolyte.
Prince Hippolyte had also come into the hall.
Prince Hippolyte stood close to the pretty, pregnant little princess.
Prince Hippolyte stared fixedly at the little princess through his eyeglass.
The little princess told Annette, "Go in, Annette, or you will catch cold."
The little princess took leave of Anna Pávlovna.
The little princess said, "It is settled," in a low voice.
Anna Pávlovna had already managed to speak to Lise about the match she contemplated between Anatole and the little princess's sister-in-law.
Anna Pávlovna said, "I rely on you, my dear," in a low tone.
Anna Pávlovna told the little princess to write to her and let her know how her father looks at the matter, then said "Au revoir!" and left the hall.
Two footmen, the little princess's footman and Prince Hippolyte's footman, stood holding a shawl and a cloak, waiting for the conversation to finish.
The footmen listened to the French sentences, which were meaningless to them, with an air of understanding but did not wish to appear to understand.
The little princess spoke smilingly.
The little princess listened with a laugh.
Prince Hippolyte said, "I am very glad I did not go to the ambassador’s," then added, "It has been a delightful evening, has it not? Delightful!"
The little princess replied, "They say the ball will be very good," and drew up her downy little lip.
The little princess said, "All the pretty women in society will be there."
Prince Hippolyte said, "Not all, for you will not be there; not all," smiling joyfully.
Prince Hippolyte snatched the shawl from the footman, pushed the footman aside, and began wrapping it around the little princess.
After adjusting the shawl, Prince Hippolyte kept his arm around the little princess for a long time, as though embracing her.
The little princess smiled, then gracefully moved away, turning and glancing at her husband, Prince Andrew.
Prince Andrew's eyes were closed.
Prince Andrew looked weary and sleepy.
Prince Andrew asked his wife, "Are you ready?" looking past her.

Prince Hippolyte hurriedly put on his cloak, which in the latest fashion reached his very heels, and, stumbling in it, ran out into the porch following the little princess, whom a footman was helping into the carriage.
Prince Hippolyte cried, "Princesse, au revoir," stumbling with his tongue as well as with his feet.
The little princess picked up her dress and was taking her seat in the dark carriage.
The little princess's husband was adjusting his saber.
Prince Hippolyte was in everyone's way under the pretense of helping.
Prince Andrew said, "Allow me, sir," in Russian in a cold, disagreeable tone to Prince Hippolyte who was blocking his path.
Prince Andrew said, "I am expecting you, Pierre," in a gentle and affectionate tone.
The postilion started.
The carriage wheels rattled.
Prince Hippolyte laughed spasmodically as he stood in the porch waiting for the vicomte whom he had promised to take home.

The vicomte said, "Well, mon cher," having seated himself beside Prince Hippolyte in the carriage, "your little princess is very nice, very nice indeed, quite French," and kissed the tips of his fingers.
Prince Hippolyte burst out laughing.
The vicomte said, "Do you know, you are a terrible chap for all your innocent airs."
The vicomte said, "I pity the poor husband, that little officer who gives himself the airs of a monarch."
The vicomte said, "And you were saying that the Russian ladies are not equal to the French? One has to know how to deal with them."
Pierre reached the house first.
Pierre went into Prince Andrew’s study.
Pierre lay down on the sofa as if quite at home.
Pierre took from the shelf the first book that came to his hand, which was Caesar’s Commentaries.
Pierre rested on his elbow and began reading the book in the middle.
Prince Andrew rubbed his small white hands.
Prince Andrew said, "What have you done to Mlle Schérer? She will be quite ill now."
Pierre turned his whole body, making the sofa creak.
Pierre lifted his eager face to Prince Andrew.
Pierre smiled.
Pierre waved his hand.
The little princess was pregnant.
